comment.author: 41097727@N00
comment._content:
I am getting sick and tired of these stupid self-serving flickr group "awards". They're just visual pollution. This "Blue Ribbon Photography" group must be quality with a K, since there are only 280,000 accepted images! Groups are great including, probably, this one but don't spam posts to promote yourselves.

This image, though, is fabulous. Love the details of the abused glass plate, the photo's depth of field...

comment.author: 12624790@N02
comment._content: The "what's this" is probably an inflated seal bladder used as a float for hunting whales or other sea going mammals.

comment.author: 15573720@N00
comment._content:
Excellent photograph!

Another take on "what's this" - I think it is an inflated seal skin.  You can see where the skin has been tied off at the neck and at the flippers.  I think it is too big to be a seal bladder.  They were used in conjunction with a harpoon.

comment._content: spectacular picture!

comment.author: 24255152@N06
comment._content: woahh

comment.author: 93432715@N00
comment._content: ndnbrueni is right - the mysterious object is a float, used in conjunction with the harpoon, for hunting. You can also see the stand on which he coils his rope, his sealskin tuilik, the bone tipped paddle in his hand and his norsaq on the harpoon. The kayak is made with a wood frame, constructed with simple mortise and tenon joins, bent ribs and lashed structure, covered with a sealskin skin. You can see the uneven stitching down the middle of the kayak. it's a classic west Greenland kayak, so that can help put a more exact location on it. For more information on the history of skin kayaks in Greenland, take a look at Harvey Golden's website, www.traditionalkayaks.com/ , and his book, Kayaks of Greenland, as well as the website for the international non profit orginization devoted to keeping this wonderful tradition alive, www.qajaqusa.org. Harvey Golden is perhaps the foremost expert on native Inuit kayaks, boats and other craft in the world, and has researched heavily with the leading experts in Greenland and Alaska.
